I've never been more sure of what my favorite game of all time is. I‚Äôve been with this game for a very very long time, watching it as it became what it is now. I started playing when it came out on the Xbox 360, and now I'm finally able to play it on Steam!

This is a game for the imaginative, the adventurers, the ones who want to test their mettle and challenge themselves. To me, this is a game of creativity, expression, and raw adventure. Let me start by simply explaining what the game is about!

Terraria is described as an action-adventure sandbox, but I think that‚Äôs a huge understatement. There‚Äôs so much in Terraria, it‚Äôs always a different experience.
‚ÄúThe Terraria adventure is truly as unique as the players themselves!‚Äù
The game has this really charming pixel art style and 2D platforming gameplay. You‚Äôre dropped into this mysterious world with a silly little guy called ‚ÄúThe Guide.‚Äù The guide gives you general tips and tells you what you can craft with items you‚Äôve found, he can tell you how to make anything. Even giving him the sword you spawn with, he tells you how to craft the best sword in the entire game. All you start out with is the skin on your back and these copper tools that you can use to start getting to work! Start chopping trees, foraging, go mining! It‚Äôs a simple start, but you quickly begin to see really what the world has to offer. The night is dangerous, so you want to either go into a cave, or build yourself a little place to call home! Terraria can be pretty unforgiving, so gear up, craft weapons, get you some armor! My best advice for a beginner, is ‚Äújust explore!!‚Äù the whole world is there! Experiment, go where it‚Äôs scary see what happens and discover. The world is also randomly generated, every world is different.
‚ÄúWill you delve deep into cavernous expanses in search of treasure and raw materials with which to craft ever-evolving gear, machinery, and aesthetics? Perhaps you will choose instead to seek out ever-greater foes to test your mettle in combat? Maybe you will decide to construct your own city to house the host of mysterious allies you may encounter along your travels?‚Äù
There‚Äôs also an evil type in each world that dictates some of the danger you‚Äôll have to face. Whichever one you choose, will be trying to consume the world and turn everything nasty.

ReLogic, the development team for Terraria, pour their heart and soul into this game. They‚Äôre kindhearted and full of imagination, and it shines in Terraria.
I‚Äôm happy to be playing a game brought by good people like them.

There‚Äôs so much detail, so much content, so much to enjoy. 5,000+ items and I never get too overwhelmed, people say you have to look up the wiki a lot, and I say otherwise. If you want something super specific, then of course look up the wiki, but I think most you can discover on your own by just playing for yourself and seeing what happens. Everything has a function or purpose, you just gotta be brave.

Let‚Äôs finally get into specifics on why this is my absolute most beloved title. 

First thing that comes to mind, the freedom of creativity. You can really build whatever or‚Ä¶ wear whatever you want! I can express myself in so many ways, hundreds of different outfits and millions of different outfit combinations. You can be really free with how you decorate too, different kinds of lights, paint literally anything too. Dye your outfit crazy colors, get dyes that give your character crazy animated effects. GET WINGS!!! I can literally wear a live rabbit on my head, how could you not love that? You can get all kinds of crazy pets and creatures, you can express yourself anyway you want.
Imagine a crystal house with a crystal toilet and put it all inside of a giant pumpkin. Literally go crazy, you are your only limit. CACTUS TOILET!!!!!!

Another big thing they do well is combat. Putting together your arsenal, and gearing yourself for a big fight is always so exciting. Will you use melee weapons? Magic Spells?? Hmm‚Ä¶ how about summoning minions to fight for you, or arming yourself with bows with enchanted arrows? Abominations are waiting for you to battle them in a fight to the death, and you‚Äôre always working towards that next big fight. It‚Äôs a really comfy progression system that always has you looking forward to conquering that next big threat!! Fighting in general is really fun too, you can get creative! Build an arena with traps for the enemy to step in, build platforms for height advantage, etc. Dodging and running around while blasting enemies with everything you‚Äôve got, using potions and anything you can to get the job done. The fights just keep getting more and more intense, so be prepared!!

Even little tasks are fun in Terraria, because they make it so accessible and worthwhile. Fishing!! Fishing is pretty rewarding and can really surprise you. Going into caves and mining, you have no idea what you‚Äôll find, the sound design is really fun too. The -tink tink tink- sounds of breaking stone is the best. Building is super fun, and can get even easier as you progress.

I already mentioned it, but lemme get a bit more into music and sound design!!
Terraria‚Äôs sound design is always fun. Even if it‚Äôs just the nasty zombie sounds, or the sound of just picking up an item or shooting an arrow. Smacking an enemy is funny, and can even make you feel powerful when it‚Äôs like firing a mini gun into a giant monstrosity. Music!! I love Terraria‚Äôs soundtrack, it‚Äôs just so funky and upbeat, while having those songs that sound sporadic and uneasy as well.

You like references? Terraria has almost any pop culture reference you can think of, maybe one of your favorite things are represented here! There‚Äôs so much to collect it‚Äôs unreal, even recently I was still discovering new stuff.

Terraria has absolutely zero microtransactions or DLC. Buying the game means you‚Äôre really buying everything they have to offer. That should be bare minimum for games, but nowadays, Terraria is one of the few exceptions.

There‚Äôs also a mode for people who just want to relax or build. It‚Äôs called journey mode, it lets you explore and work for your rewards, but in a much more comfy way without the big challenge and demand of the main portion of the game. That mode is welcome for anyone who‚Äôs new or just need a comfier experience.
Though I already think Terraria is a very comfy game, it can be pretty dangerous still.

Co-op mode is also very fun, nothing beats playing games with friends.

Overall, I have barely anything negative to say about the game, but I‚Äôll try to find some gripes to be fair.

It can be hard to tell how to progress, and a lot of things happen to just happen. To me, I like that because it encourages really exploring and thinking for yourself without anything holding your hand. But I totally understand how people can be turned away by that.

Another gripe might be that it‚Äôs hard to get exactly what you want when customizing, but it‚Äôs impossible for a game to literally have anything you want.

Some stuff can be too vague, and some stuff is just plain frustrating, but it all pales in comparison to the positives.


Now, it‚Äôs finally time for me to wrap up. Thank you for reading.

To me, Terraria is a work of art, and a love letter to all video games and those who play them. ReLogic did a stellar job making something truly special.

Terraria is that kind of game you download thinking you‚Äôll just play for a bit, and suddenly you‚Äôve been mining for hours without even noticing. It‚Äôs way deeper than it looks. There‚Äôs always something new to do ‚Äî a place to explore, a weird item to craft, or some crazy idea to try out. I finished it on mobile, and now I plan to beat it on PC too!

The crafting system is simply genius. There are combinations that feel like a joke ‚Äî you throw together a bunch of totally random stuff and end up with an item that completely changes the game. It‚Äôs the kind of thing that makes you think, ‚Äúwho was the mad genius that came up with this?‚Äù And the best part is, somehow, everything makes sense in the chaos that is Terraria.

The sense of progression is addictive. You start with a wooden sword, and before you know it, you‚Äôre summoning bosses with random items and using ridiculous weapons. Every achievement feels like a real victory, and it keeps you wanting to play just to see what comes next.

Terraria is one of those games that never gets old. Even after so many hours, there‚Äôs still something new to discover. I plan to play until I get everything, because honestly, it‚Äôs one of the most amazing games I‚Äôve ever played!.

Terraria is one of those rare games that never truly gets old. It looks simple at first glance ‚Äî a 2D pixel sandbox that feels like a cousin of Minecraft ‚Äî but the more you play, the deeper it gets.

Every moment feels rewarding: exploring the massive world, fighting unique bosses, discovering hidden treasures, and building crazy structures with complete freedom. The progression is perfectly paced ‚Äî you start with a wooden sword and end up facing gods and cosmic horrors with weapons that feel earned, not handed to you.

What I love most is how every playthrough feels different. The biomes, loot, and even the bosses push you to experiment and try new strategies. The soundtrack, pixel art, and overall vibe make it strangely relaxing and thrilling at the same time.

Terraria is basically endless adventure, creativity, and chaos ‚Äî all in one game.
If you like Minecraft, crafting, or any game that rewards curiosity, this is an absolute must-play.

‚≠ê 10/10 ‚Äî Timeless sandbox perfection.

I'm surprised I didn't write a review for this game yet.

Terraria is not really a beginner-friendly game. You're likely going to need to reference the wiki often or, and I prefer this suggestion, play with a friend.

But when you really get into the game, whether vanilla or modded, it gets GOOD. It's all about learning every part of the game and having a clearer image of what you want to do.

In addition, the game's difficulty options allow for a wide selection of play: Classic for newer players, Expert for most, Master mode if you want a challenge, and then there's seeds that add extra challenge, alongside Journey Mode, which, depending on how you play, is less of a difficulty and more of a built in QoL mod.

Terraria review: is this a trap?

I got this game back in 2015 with some birthday money. It was right before the release of version 1.3 (expert mode) I had no idea the lasting impact this ‚Äúcute 2d mine/build/loot em‚Äô up‚Äù would have on my gaming life. 

I remember how I started a normal world and had so much fun exploring every corner and dodging all the traps. I did my best to play blind and WOW did I do things terribly. I knew I needed to look some stuff up after I killed wall of flesh and immediately died 100 times in a row to normal hardmode mobs. To get around in hard mode I would utilize the terrain WAY TO MUCH. I was so scared of getting killed that I would make a tunnel right under the surface with doors every few hundred tiles to I could move around the world in hard mode a bit easier. I was seriously frustrated and had hit a wall in my progress. So I decided to start a new world with the just released expert mode. This time, with knowledge on my side! 

I learned the many ways to utilize the hoik bug/feature and made a trap. This marked the beginning of becoming a full-fledged Terrarian! Expert mode was hard at first, but I quickly learned how to better utilize mobility add ons and how to use the guide for crafting recipes. I progressed through expert mode until I hit the moonlord. I COULD NOT DEFEAT THAT GUY. I went back to my normal mode world and continued where I had left off with all this expert mode loot! Moonlord was a breeze in normal mode which gave me the loot I thought I needed to defeat expert moonlord. With the hardest foe defeated (at the time), I was too powerful. I realized that I used end game weapons from my normal world, so my victory was a hollow one. So, I made a new character(s)

This is where I really leaned into my own personal lore for my characters. I had only made softcore characters up to this point but wanted that extra challenge, so I made a world for hardcore characters only. At this point you may think that I tried hard and succeeded but that isn‚Äôt the truth. I was never able to get much farther than the EOC until my character would die. You lose EVERYTHING with hardcore characters. I ended making 30+ hardcore characters and each one of them died. I eventually made softcore character for that world but just to gather all the head stones, no progression. To this day this world is stuck between EOC and EOW. I built a nice graveyard for all the fallen hardcore characters. This brings me to my next point.

Building. This game has endless possibilities for cute buildings and landscapes. I have crafted all kinds of villages, castles, and underground bunkers. I even made a world where I mined EVERY BLOCK. The building and mining system in this game is such a treat. You can find paintings in the wild and earn other wall hangers from the fisherman. You can paint walls and dye clothes! I love to put a green dye on the peddler‚Äôs hat (You‚Äôll love/hate how you get the peddler‚Äôs hat!) Making decorated fishing holes and mob farms remains one of my favorite pass times. 

I‚Äôm so impressed with all the content this game offers. Development was supposed to end over 10 years ago but it‚Äôs still going! No doubt a testament to the replay value of the game. So much love and care went into every aspect on top of timely fixes if anything was too buggy. While I am satisfied with the game. I look forward to all the new additions and crossovers. 

Overall, this is my most played game according to steam. I highly recommend it. It won‚Äôt hold your hand, but it WILL taunt you into progressing. 

 ‚ÄúThey say there is a person who will tell you how to survive in this land... oh wait. That's me." ‚Äì The Guide

This Review is long overdue if i'm going to be completely honest. I love how unique the bosses are. and the gameplay progression is genuinely good. also the amount of detail put into this game is crazy, there are so many different things you can do. play this game.

Terraria at its core is simple: gather resources, fight bosses, gather more resources, and repeat. In the end, you look back at what you‚Äîand maybe your friends‚Äîaccomplished. Was all that time spent worth it in the end?
When I first started playing, my friend guided me through the game. Throughout it, I barely learned anything for myself. To me, the game felt empty‚Äîall that time spent and nothing to show for it. But that wasn‚Äôt the end for me. The reason my friend had rushed me through the base game was so we could join another friend in a mod called Calamity.
When I first entered Calamity, I had no idea what to expect. I kept asking my friends for advice on what to do, but when they didn‚Äôt give much, I stuck with the only thing I knew‚Äîthe melee class. It didn‚Äôt matter much at first since they carried me through most of it. But then came one boss that changed everything: Providence.
The problem with Providence was that if one person died, it would randomly despawn. And the person it always targeted was me‚Äîthe melee class, the tank, the frontline, the shield. After failing many times, I realized that it wasn‚Äôt us that was the problem‚Äîit was me. I had hit a wall with no way around. I had failed my friends. What do you even do in that situation? And this wasn‚Äôt even the final boss.
So, I did the only thing I could‚Äîlearn, research, and adapt. It might seem small, but it was exactly what we needed. Immediately, I felt the difference. No longer was I at the bottom; I finally felt like I could stand side by side with my friends.
This was the peak of Terraria for me. My performance skyrocketed, and together we managed to beat a glitched Providence. But that wasn‚Äôt all‚Äîarmed with my newfound skill, we blasted through the next few bosses until we reached D.O.G. My friends had told me it took them forever to defeat him before. Could I really stand a chance? Had I actually improved, or was it just a fluke?
Well, I would have thought that‚Äîif we hadn‚Äôt beaten him on the first try. And D.O.G wasn‚Äôt the only one. We cleared the rest of the bosses with little to no issues and finally beat Calamity.
Sure, Terraria is simple at its core, but it‚Äôs so much more than that. Not only have I beaten the game and faced everything it threw at me, but I‚Äôve also found new things to love‚Äîlike dyes, customization, and building. And in the end, when I look back at what my friends and I managed to accomplish, I realize there‚Äôs still so much more to do.

This is my favorite game of all time, its perfect for people who love the pixelated look of some games and additionally love decorating. Also the progression for bosses is seamless, each boss that is ordered is ordered in such a way that the difficulty makes sense and the gear prepares you for harder bosses. The team behind this game also takes plenty of time to make every update fit the game like a patchwork quilt, homemade by someone who cares. Terraria is an experience everyone needs to at least try once.

This is a game that is unlike any other. It is unique in that it takes elements from different styles of gameplay, giving you feelings of "Oh, this is like Minecraft!" or "Oh, this is like Stardew Valley!" or "Oh I played a game like this when I was a kid!" and then elevates every element of it. As a result you have this game that starts off feeling tiny and are given the world and beyond to explore, create, and adventure. Like Stardew, a lot of the game is going to be dependent on either following a wiki or asking friends for help, but this game is already so much fun that you will be excited to learn more about the different possibilities and wonders that you can unlock that you will end up thinking about it all the time, and wishing to return to the world every time you have been away for a while. Genuinely, such a fun and creative experience!

Terraria isn‚Äôt just a sandbox ‚Äî it‚Äôs a true adventure. I started in Journey Mode, learning and building at my own pace, and ended in Master Mode, facing every challenge the game could offer. Each step felt rewarding, from discovering new biomes to finally defeating the toughest bosses.

The pixel art, music, and freedom to create make it endlessly replayable. Even after finishing all modes, it still feels fresh every time I return.

A beautiful journey from start to finish. One of the best games ever made. üåüüíñ
